qas.question: Why is Bermuda considered an offshore financial center?

answers.text: minimal standards of business regulation/laws and direct taxation on personal or corporate income

qas.question: What does it do in place of an income tax system?
What does Bermuda use the consumption tax for?
What three things does the tax system depend on?

answers.text: import duties, payroll taxes and consumption taxes

qas.question: What is Bermuda's legal system derived from?

answers.text: United Kingdom, with recourse to English courts of final appeal

qas.question: What country uses an income tax in lieu of an import tax?
What is Bermuda's income tax used to fund?
What is derived from the English courts?

plausible_answers.text: open bank accounts or subscribe to mobile phone or internet services.

qas.question: What can foreign private individuals easily do?

context: <b5_0>Bermuda<b5_0/> is an offshore financial centre, which results from its <a0_0>minimal standards of business regulation/laws and direct taxation on personal or corporate income<a0_0/>. It has one of the highest consumption taxes in the world and <a1_0>taxes all imports<a1_0/> in lieu of an income tax system. Bermudas's consumption tax is equivalent to local income tax to local residents and <a2_0>funds <b6_0>government and infrastructure expenditures<b6_0/><a2_0/>. The local tax system depends upon <a3_0>import duties, payroll taxes and consumption taxes<a3_0/>. <b7_0>The legal system<b7_0/> is derived from that of the <a4_0>United Kingdom, with recourse to English courts of final appeal<a4_0/>. Foreign private individuals cannot easily <b8_0>open bank accounts or subscribe to mobile phone or internet services.
